captions.text: three...
two...
one. Fuck it.
Gimme ! Fuck it !

- Get out of here !
- l'm stayin' right here !

- Get outta here !
- l'm stayin' right here.

- l'll blow your fuckin' head off !
- Then do it !

You want to do it ?
Do it ! Let's go.

- [ Click ]
- Fuck.
Get outta here !

You fucked up, all right ?
So what ?

So everybody does it.
Get on with your life, would ya ?

What life ?
l got no life !
l'm in the dark here !

You understand ?
l'm in the dark !

So give up. You want
to give up, give up...
'cause l'm givin' up too.

You said l'm through.
You're right.

We're both through.
It's all over.

So let's get on with it.
Let's fuckin' do it.

Let's fuckin' pull the trigger,
you miserable blind motherfucker.
Pull the trigger.
Here we go, Charlie.
l'm ready.
You don't want to die.
And neither do you.
Give me one reason not to.

l'll give you two. you can
dance the tango and drive a Ferrari...

better than anyone
l've ever seen.

You never seen anyone
do either.
Give me the gun, Colonel.

Oh, where do l go
from here, Charlie ?

lf you're tangled up,
just tango on.

You askin' me
to dance, Charlie ?

title: Scent of a Woman (7/8) Movie CLIP - I'm In the Dark (1992) HD

comments.text:
Chills every time I see this scene. He delivers it was such sincerity. So 
many can relate to that simple line in so many ways for so many reasons. 
Only Pacino could pull this off.﻿

comments.author: jay t cache

comments.text:
It's a shame that we don't have enough films like this around anymore. This 
generation gets remakes, re-boots, sequels, and super hero movie after 
super hero movie. THIS is an absolute classic. It's rare to a performance 
(by both actors) quite as mesmerizing as this. It is thrilling and full of 
heart. You care about these characters. 
Half the movies I see nowadays just feels...empty. This was full of life.﻿
comments.author: Mark Hazleton

comments.text: This scene is so sad isnt it﻿

comments.author: CorvusOfMellori

comments.text:
Chris O'Donnell's performance in this scene is WAY underrated....."you can 
dance the tango and drive a Ferrari better than anyone I've ever seen." 
..... "get on with your life already"...."I'm ready"..... "If you get 
tangled up..... you just Tango on" etc.
We won't even GO THERE with Pacino... HE is a Master! As is Brest.OBVIOUSLY.
and screenwriters ....BRILLIANT! .......probably among the most moving 
scenes in the film.
yeah, yeah, yeah... the tango scene memorable, as is the "Cradle of 
Leadership" monologue. But this is....intense. ﻿

comments.author: Kim Rosenkrone

comments.text:
I thought about suicide also, when i was 17, now im 19, and this movies 
helped me even more to see that life is on, that everything is connected in 
such a perfect and beautiful way, that even the darkest and saddest moments 
of life like this one, leads to an anwser, a solution, a almost invisible 
tiny path that God or wathever you gonna call it, no matters what your 
religion is, even if you dont have any, that interior partner that you feel 
in your soul when you are alone, is always there, leading you trought life, 
no matter how empty and dark it is, he always has everything figured out, 
and all those ones who commits suicide, its because they rejected that 
interior kidness, that we all in this world, no matter how evil we are, 
even Hitler or Lucifer had just a small and almost invisibly piece of love, 
that always guide us, that piece of soul that keep as alive, and all those 
who comitted suicide, rejected the help of that soul, because that how it 
is, and this movie shows it, in a perfect way, how other life, that you was 
almost seconds close to take it, before taking yours, can change 
everything, and give you that light you need to see the path of real life, 
that's why he's blind, its a metaphor. I cant believe how much this movie 
transmits, and how much it transmited me particulary because of my almost 
suicide attempts and dark moments, when i was in the dark, the fog, the 
pain, like Pacino expressed. This movie is Art.﻿
comments.author: john hamlet

comments.author: ‫عائشہ اسماعیل‬‎

comments.text:
+kaled009 hahaha...there is the popular "tango scene" the "Going for a ride 
in the Ferrari" the Thanksgiving Dinner" scene of course, the famous 
soliloquy where he stands up for Charles and speaks of the CRADLE of 
LEADERSHIP..."be careful what kind of leaders you are creating here and 
Beard Bums....and there is nothing like the sight of an amputated spirit" 
need I go on? =D =D =D

 p.s. Funny moments also..such as the "yabba dabba doo comments he 
initially makes about his sister, husband and the kids...."John 
Daniels...when you've known him as long as I have" etc.
But what impresses me most, is that the effect he had on Charlie was 
reciprocated, probably 10 fold by the effect Charlie had on HIM. That 
weekend, turned him into a changed man, who once again found purpose in 
life and realized.....there was indeed....HOPE.
"How's THAT for Korn ball?" ;)

comments.text:
+Aaron Simpson The performance and film.....amazing! Direction, screenplay, 
etc. Pacino was nominated for an Oscar, too many times to count. "Academy 
Awards" mean nothing to me. However, he and this film are just one of too 
many others to mention that are equally as powerful. I could list at least 
another 50 "gushers" as you say. There is indeed a difference between fine 
film, and just another "movie." Yes. This is a classic.Look up Dustin 
Hoffman's speech at the Oscars when he accepted the AC Award for Kramer vs. 
Kramer....circa 1977 (?) It says it all.

It's so sad because even though he is blind Colonel Slade is still the 
maverick he's always been. But as always he's too proud to admit it until 
Charlie threw himself in the path of the proverbial (and almost literal) 
bullet to save him. Amazing scene and move. One of my all-favorites.﻿

integrity.   Thereafter,   the Colonel saved Charlie too but this time from 
getting expelled.
